授業目的: The purpose of this course is for students to learn the basics of Canadian government and discuss political issues that will shape the future for young people in Canada and Japan.
到達目標:
Students will:
• Understand the basics of democratic government
• Discuss "hot" political issues in Canada and Japan: the COVID-19 pandemic; climate change and climate action; social equality; the status of women; immigration, diversity and inclusion; the rights of Indigenous (First) Canadians; sexual orientation; sex work.
• Learn how to write and present short “briefing notes” on political issues
授業方法: Learning activities include lectures by the Professor, student discussions and short student presentations. The Professor's presentation will be available on LUNA before each course session. The Professor's presentations will be available on LUNA before each course session to make it easier for students to understand and take notes.

評価.成績評価Grading4:
備考　Note
Students will write two short (1000–1200 words) “briefing notes” on course topics of their choice. A briefing note gives the reader a basic understanding of a selected topic (e.g., climate change) and what government is doing about it (e.g., taxing fossil fuel producers). Sources can include short media reports and other credible on-line sources (e.g., the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change). Each student will also give a short (5-10 minute) in-class presentation on a course topic of their choice; this presentation can be on the same topic covered in a student's written briefing note (e.g., family caregivers). Students will receive marks for attendance and participation.

Briefing Note 1: 20%
Briefing Note 2: 30%
In-Class Presentation: 30%
Attendance & Participation: 20%

Assignments must be submitted by the due date or they will not be graded. If students require additional time to complete an assignment because of illness or personal difficulties, an extension must be negotiated with the Professor before the due date.
